name: Academic Building Blocks
description: 30 words commonly encountered in high school academics

words.definition: Examine in detail to understand or explain.
examples: Scientists analyze data to find patterns.
We need to analyze the problem before solving it.

words.definition: Accept as true without proof; take on a role.
examples: Don't assume you know the answer.
She assumed the position of team leader.

words.definition: Bring to an end; reach a judgment after reasoning.
examples: The study concluded that exercise improves mood.
We concluded the meeting at noon.

words.definition: Clearly show the existence or truth of something.
examples: The experiment demonstrates the principle clearly.
She demonstrated excellent leadership skills.

words.definition: Assess the value or quality of something.
examples: Teachers evaluate student progress regularly.
We need to evaluate all our options.

words.definition: Explain the meaning of something.
examples: How do you interpret this poem?
The data can be interpreted in different ways.

words.definition: Show or prove to be right or reasonable.
examples: Can you justify your decision?
The ends don't justify the means.

words.definition: Give a brief statement of the main points.
examples: Please summarize the article in one paragraph.
Let me summarize what we've discussed.

words.definition: A particular way of viewing things; point of view.
examples: Try to see it from her perspective.
The book offers a fresh perspective on history.

words.definition: A result or effect of an action.
examples: He suffered the consequences of his actions.
Climate change has serious consequences.

words.definition: Have an effect on character, development, or behavior.
examples: Parents influence their children's values.
The weather influenced our decision.

words.definition: Buy or obtain for oneself; learn or develop.
examples: She acquired a taste for classical music.
The company acquired several smaller firms.

words.definition: Adjust to new conditions; modify for a new use.
examples: Animals adapt to their environment.
The book was adapted into a movie.

words.definition: Expect or predict; look forward to.
examples: We anticipate a large turnout.
She anticipated his every move.

words.definition: A part or element of a larger whole.
examples: Trust is a key component of any relationship.
The engine has many components.

words.definition: An abstract idea or general notion.
examples: The concept of justice varies across cultures.
It's a difficult concept to grasp.

words.definition: Acting the same way over time; compatible.
examples: She has been consistent in her efforts.
The data is consistent with our theory.

words.definition: Set up on a permanent basis; prove beyond doubt.
examples: The company was established in 1950.
We need to establish the facts first.

words.definition: Information indicating whether something is true.
examples: The evidence clearly supports this theory.
There is no evidence of wrongdoing.

words.definition: A circumstance that contributes to a result.
examples: Cost is an important factor in our decision.
Many factors contributed to the outcome.

words.definition: Cause something to arise or come about.
examples: The project will generate new jobs.
Solar panels generate electricity.

words.definition: A proposed explanation based on limited evidence.
examples: The scientist tested her hypothesis.
Our hypothesis was proven correct.

words.definition: Point out or show; be a sign of.
examples: The survey indicates strong support.
Red lights indicate danger.

words.definition: Carry out research or inquiry into something.
examples: Police are investigating the incident.
Scientists investigate natural phenomena.

words.definition: Cause to continue; keep in good condition.
examples: It's important to maintain good health.
She maintained her innocence throughout.

words.definition: Get or acquire something.
examples: You need to obtain permission first.
She obtained a degree in physics.

words.definition: Having capacity to develop; latent qualities.
examples: She has great potential as a leader.
There is potential for growth in this market.

words.definition: A fundamental truth or belief; a rule of conduct.
examples: The principle of equality is fundamental.
She refused to compromise her principles.

words.definition: Based on truth or reason; legally acceptable.
examples: Is your passport still valid?
She made a valid point.

words.definition: In contrast or comparison with the fact that.
examples: She loves summer, whereas he prefers winter.
The first plan failed, whereas the second succeeded.
